sub_topic: Calculation of heat capacity of a substance
message_1: What is the heat capacity of a 25 g sample of iron, when heated from 25°C to 150°C, given that the specific heat capacity of iron is 0.45 J/g°C?
message_2:
To find the heat capacity of the 25 g sample of iron, we can use the formula:

q = mcΔT

where q is the heat capacity, m is the mass of the sample, c is the specific heat capacity of the substance, and ΔT is the change in temperature.

Given:
m = 25 g
c = 0.45 J/g°C
Initial temperature (T1) = 25°C
Final temperature (T2) = 150°C

First, we need to find the change in temperature (ΔT):
ΔT = T2 - T1 = 150°C - 25°C = 125°C

Now, we can plug the values into the formula:
q = (25 g) × (0.45 J/g°C) × (125°C)

q = 25 × 0.45 × 125
q = 11.25 × 125
q = 1406.25 J

The heat capacity of the 25 g sample of iron when heated from 25°C to 150°C is 1406.25 J.
